qas.question: All Slavic vernaculars were called what among Romans?
Who is considered the most competent Serbian scientist on language?
Which language does Milan Resetar state that Dubrovnik derived from?
What does the opinion of Roman inhabitants not have?
What were all Croatian vernaculars called among Romans?

plausible_answers.text: "The one who thinks that Croatian and Serbian are two separate languages must confess that Dubrovnik always (linguistically) used to be Serbian."

qas.question: What did Roman inhabitants write about Croatian and Serbian?
Who is the most competent Croatian scientist on language?

context: On the other hand, the opinion of Jagić from 1864 is argued not to have <b4_0>firm grounds<b4_0/>. When Jagić says "Croatian", he refers to a few cases referring to the Dubrovnik vernacular as <b5_0>ilirski <a0_0>(Illyrian)<b5_0/><a0_0/>. This was a common name for all Slavic vernaculars in Dalmatian cities among the Roman inhabitants. In the meantime, other written monuments are found that mention srpski, lingua serviana (= Serbian), and some that mention Croatian. By far the most competent Serbian scientist on the Dubrovnik language issue, <a1_0><b8_0>Milan Rešetar<b8_0/><a1_0/>, who was born in <a2_0><b6_0>Dubrovnik<b6_0/><a2_0/> himself, wrote behalf of language characteristics: <b7_0>"The one who thinks that Croatian and Serbian are two separate languages must confess that Dubrovnik always (linguistically) used to be <a3_0>Serbian<a3_0/>."
